subject: Personal Finance
title: Cost-Push Inflation
description: A short lesson to help you apply Cost-Push Inflation.

hook.text: Oil prices tripled in 1973. Suddenly everything made with oil â€” which is everything â€” got expensive.

buildup.text: Cost-push inflation happens when the cost of producing goods rises and businesses pass it on.

discovery.text: Rising wages, raw material costs, or supply disruptions all push production costs up.

twist.text: This type is harder to fight. Raising interest rates slows demand but doesn't fix supply problems.

climax.text: The 1970s 'stagflation' combined rising prices with a stagnant economy â€” cost-push at its worst.

punchline.text: When making things costs more, buying them does too.

quiz.question: What is cost-push inflation?
options: Rising production costs passed on to consumers
